p.s: Through the use of many stylistic devices such as parallelisms and comparisons and first naming the problem then many solutions Boris Johnson created an overall hopefull and optimistic connotation.
By starting with a James Bond reference (l. 2) Johnson on the one hand loosens up his speech, talking about a popular movie and on the other hand shows the tradgedytragedy of the problem.

In the entire speech he never mentions one problem climate change is already causing or will cause thus the problemprobem seems rather theoretical, even though he continues to mention the urgency to act now when he continues to talk about the empty promises of the past.
Through repeating that he was at past conferences about climate changes he creates the feeling that he knows what to do (ll. 10).
He as well as everyone else around the globae had to listen to the empty promises.

This creates the feeling that we are all in the same boat which is also emphasized by the repetition of I was there (ll. 10), the use of the informal phrase blah, blah, blah (l. 13) and inclusive language (l. 6, 30, 46).
After pointing out the urgency to act now he then goes on talking about the things we can do to stop the man-made climate change.
He sets a quietquite optimisic tone by again using a repetition we can.We can get real (l. 16).
This optimistic tone also was created through his argumentativargumentative structure so far.
He first described the problem (l. 1) and then named ways to solve it (l. 16) thus creating a feeling of hope in his audience.
By telling his listeners that the UK has already ended their dependence on coal and the use of a comparison (l. 29) he shows that his strategies already have worked and will also work in the future.
This enlages the audience's trust in him.
Further he uses future generations as an emotional pressure tool.
Most of the people he is talking to have children for which they probably only want to the bst future.
They also do not want them to think badly about their parents and grantparentsgrand-parents, wishing they would have acted differently.
This is also underlined by his use of the metaphor fluff our lives or miss our cue (l. 40).
After that he creates the picture that we already have everything we need to act by using a parallelism (ll. 46) making the acting itself seem easy.
By in the end referring to James Bond (l. 48) again Boris Johnson closes the frame.
This also has a positive connotation because in the most cases James Bond movies have a happy ending, implying the climate crisis will so, too.
All in all you can see that Johnson successfully tries to give hope to his audience and showshows that he and the rest of the world are capable of solving the issue of climate change.
